title: Thursday, 27th September 2018
bodyHTML:

Drago Hola.

Anyway, this is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's immovable obstacle in my daily workflow.

AlexJames Greencore

Peanut Used to be NH and PM
11:12 am

Unanimous decision. Wording of the statement largely unchanged from August.

Excel Developer ueah, PM,NH at first then OPM went off to do Tilt (an EM proj) so became NH,BE, then PM came back PM,BE
BE11:12am

Moving to Natixis ......

BE11:12am

The only surprise was that the Committee deleted the sentence to the effect monetary policy was accommodating (in the August statement, it stated that “the stance of monetary policy remains accommodative, thereby supporting strong labor market conditions and a sustained return to 2 percent inflation”). While this modification was initially perceived as a dovish move, Fed Chair Jerome Powell then emphasized that this did not signal any change in the likely path of policy, simply a revision of the Federal Reserve’s communication.

Grouchmonkey Bore Da
11:13 am
BE11:13am

And in terms of the bloody dots.

BE11:13am

The median of the FOMC members’ expectations for the Fed Funds rate (i.e. the dots) is little changed for 2018, signalling that one more interest rate hike is expected in December. The median was also unchanged for 2019 and 2020, with three hikes expected next year and just one hike in 2020. Only the longer run median came in for an upward revision, probably attributable to the inclusion of the projections by Richard Clarida, the new Vice-Chair. However, revisions to the dots were in majority on the upside on the whole, save in 2020 when they are now more concentrated around the median. All in all, the Federal Reserve still anticipates there being a gradual tightening, with an overshooting of the longer run neutral interest rate level from end-2019.

BE11:14am

.... so, we're down to analysing how long Powell speaks.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Generally speaking, the Federal Reserve’s communication under Jerome Powell has tended to become more concise. The FOMC statement has undergone a further shrink, while press conferences are shorter on average. The message coming from the Fed Chair remains consistent with his latest speeches, not really shedding any new light. The description of the policy remains largely positive, with inflation expected to land around the official target. Jerome Powell acknowledged that trade tensions constituted a risk on the downside but that, as yet, no negative effects had been observed.

BE11:14am

Etc etc etc.

Drago I feel like the Fed has become more boring under Powell.
BE11:15am

Here's Goldman.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

The FOMC also took small further steps toward clarifying its plan to manage the labor market overshoot. In the new 2021 projections, the unemployment rate rises slightly toward NAIRU as the policy stance remains modestly restrictive. Powell noted that moving to a restrictive stance is “very possible” and would be a historically normal step, that policy decisions will be pragmatic and not overly reliant on neutral rate estimates, and that those estimates could also rise.
n We continue to expect 4 rate hikes in total in 2018 and 4 more in 2019 for a terminal rate of 3.25-3.5%, with the risks skewed to the upside. Our subjective odds of a hike at the December meeting are 85%.

Drago I miss the Greenspan days when he was talking about the markets and public policy and pretty much everything.
financing donkey Clinigen?
Soundbuy Speaking of Goldman................understand the history but a bank called Marcus............zzzzz...........its a bit Dave...........
BE11:16am

And Nomura.

BE11:16am

A case of the “cannot shake those dovish feelings” or not hawkish enough?
Although the Fed largely delivered on our economist’s base-case expectations (in terms of their forecast and statement changes) instead of eliciting a neutral-to-slightly hawkish response, as we were anticipating, the bond market sharply rallied into the close seemingly in line with a selloff in the equity market.
What took place intra-day is revealing, however, and suggests that markets still yearn for dovish Fed hikes, in our view. Off the back of the morning trading session, the bond market was already rallying. It then gapped after the removal of the accommodation language. But early in Powell’s press conference pared back the earlier day’s gains. That slight reversal ultimately ended up being a head fake as rates proceeded to rally again as the equity market sold off.
Taking a quick look at our FOMC scenarios (see link) the “close to close” move was more in line with what we would have expected for a dovish Fed hike (with 10yr rates rallying nearly 5bp on the day). Today’s bond market move also erases the rise in rates experienced over the last 5 trading days. As seen in Figure 4, this has happened before but we are surprised it happened now given where we are in the cycle. Given the rise in rates into the meeting, perhaps the overall message was not hawkish enough.
Nonetheless the bond market was setup to find a reason to rally and thus we got the standard “sell into the Fed, buy right afterward” trade. The market seems to be wired to pick up on dovish tones, especially as chair Powell spoke about inflation as not a serious cause for concern yet. The other potential dovish signals that triggered the markets was that the 2021 median dot was the same as the 2020 median (the first time they signal that they are going on hold in the near future). Lastly, equities had a large decline after chair Powell mentioned valuations are at the upper-end of historical ranges.
The bond market is now moving on to other topics that lie ahead (in the near term, its quarter-end portfolio rebalancing, in the medium term, tariffs and the mid-term elections). To reignite the urge for rates to sell off from here might need global rates higher and/or Fed speakers coming out to clarify that the market’s misread the message. The overall one day move is not enough to set a trend, so we maintain our view that they are still hiking while global supply is ballooning, which will serve to push up rates into year-end.

Swedish Chef @Grouch Saesneg Yma, dwi’n meddwl:-)
nightingale20201 morning all...is there a consensus to the fact that he current FED is pretty reactive, data dependent would probably overshoot the tightening on the upside..?

Indivior PLC (INDV:LSE): Last: 180.20, down 34.8 (-16.19%), High: 211.20, Low: 179.10, Volume: 5.58m

Another profit warning, delivered late yesterday.

Blank canvas Greencore

Lowered to $8-10m from $25-50m

11:22 am

You remember the argument here. Sublocade's meant to compensate for the other artificial scag coming off patent but so far doctors and/or insurers have been, "uh, no."

Blank canvas It reminds me of Who Framed Roger Rabbit -"Shave and a haircut ..."
BE11:23am

Indivior's keeping peak sales guidance of more than $1bn, suggesting it thinks the scrip hurdles can be crossed eventually.

BE11:24am

But, realistically, the current run rate suggests peak would be a decade away, if you're lucky.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

So ....... forecasts get smashed. Here's Jefferies.

BE11:24am

We lower EPS by more than 50% 2020+ as a delayed Sublocade ramp-up significantly impacts a largely fixed cost base despite cost savings. NT we increase EPS by 23% in 2018 as cost savings more than compensate for the delta to Sublocade. In 2019 with further savings, this mutes the Sublocade decline resulting in a 7% cut. Our updated SOTP is 250p.

Waterloo Powell also said that while it's not in his remit, he'd be using the strong economy to start bringing down debt.
BE11:26am

Numis is more bullish based on eventual need.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Our fundamental stance remains that Suboxone dailies have failed to halt the escalating epidemic, and that the longer-acting Sublocade is needed to improve patient compliance and increase physician acceptance although clearly greater patience will be needed to see the ramp. SOTP based valuation now implies a 350p price target, with the shares trading on 11x our consensus low EV/EBITDA forecasts for FY19.

VV75 Any comment on IG Group's rather hefty nosedive on CEO departure?
BE11:27am

The positive in the statement is that film sales are stabilising. But that's just because Dr Reddy's has an injunction against it, right?

BE11:28am

Anyway, the warning's only two or so weeks since Indivior reiterated guidance so the market reaction is understandable.

11:28 am
undefined
Blue horseshoe... WPP....rerating?
Fox Can I request some commentary on SAGA's H1 results please?
Soundbuy IG Grp - 34p divi there?
BE11:29am

IG Group ..... and farewell Peter Hetherington.

BE11:30am

Who joined IG in January 1994 on the grad trainee scheme, and had been CEO since October 2015.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Statement is a bit weird ......

BE11:30am

The Company has been considering as part of its normal succession planning process the leadership characteristics it needs for the next stage of its development. The Board has focused on finding a CEO with wide global experience of the broader financial sector who can develop the business using its industry-leading technology platform, geographic presence and product innovation as a base.

BE11:31am

Does this suggest he's been pushed?

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Or that there's been a scrap at board level over how to cope with ESMA?

BE11:31am

Barclays doesn't know, but is happy to speculate.

BE11:31am

This could be interpreted as a different skill set than that of the outgoing CEO, who has been with IG for 24 years, and therefore whose knowledge arguably pertains first and foremost to IG’s heritage: spread betting, CFDs, and risk management. Whilst we cannot know for sure from the outside, the wording in the quote above “has been considering” also suggests that the Board has been considering this succession issue for some time, rather than a major fall out between CEO and the Board. This is potentially a generous interpretation, but is still quite different to what happened when Peter Hetherington became CEO, when the previous CEO (Tim Howkins) and CFO (Chris Hill) both left the business in quick succession, and there was not adequate succession planning in place.

11:32 am
IG Group Holdings PLC (IGG:LSE): Last: 646.50, down 87 (-11.86%), High: 680.00, Low: 645.50, Volume: 2.62m
BE11:33am

As noted on the right, that's 33.51p of ex div, or 4.57 percentage points of the drop.

BE11:34am

Barclays is happy to hold for yield alone.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Overall, we still believe there will be unanswered questions for some time, as we believe shareholders held Mr Hetherington in high regard, and this may amplify concerns about the effect of regulation. However, assuming nothing more meaningful has happened than described in the statement, and assuming regulation effect is broadly consistent with our forecasts, we believe times like now with potential share price weakness should be used by shareholders to step in and add to positions in what is a global leader in its field. We rated Peter Hetherington highly as CEO, but in a company that generated PBT of more than £280m in FY18 and now offers a dividend yield of c6%, we believe that the show will go on under a new CEO.

VV75 live quote @6.355, that's still close to a 10% drop

Buying Jam Group, Canada's premier (possibly) distributor of microphones and tube amplifiers and stuff like that.

VV75 book just closed on their placing, it's at 68
Upaswellasdown morning all. Clinigen pls

BE11:40am

Here's Caz.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

DCC has announced a three-part update, including an encouraging trading update, a 4.5% accretive US Technology acquisition and a proposed 10% equity placing to fuel further M&A. We view the placing as a strong indicator of the level of M&A available to DCC. We note that DCC has spent £270m on M&A in H1, compared to an FY16-18 full-year average
of £448m – indicating an accelerating trend. Our forecasts include the
impact of the acquisition, but do not include the equity placing. Our
FY19e and FY20e EPS rise by 1.9% and 4.5%, respectively. We remain
OW.

VV75 well ok, it's 6800
BE11:41am

And Davy.

BE11:42am

[Pro music kit is] expected to grow at 2-4% CAGR to 2022. Jam has a very broad vendor and customer list, distributing more than 500 third party brands to c.6,000 B2B and retail customers. It generated revenues of $323m in the year to April 2018 and has an operating margin of c.7.5%. DCC also continues to deploy capital at attractive rates of return. The transaction multiple equates to c.6.7x EBIT, c.15% ROCE in
the first full year of ownership, similar to the Stampede and Kondor deals in July.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Why would music kit be 2-4% CAGR to 2022?

BE11:43am

There's no great need to ship FL Studio plugins.

BE11:44am

Twelve months ago, DCC had no presence in the US. The US now accounts for 14% of group capital employed, with three platforms across LPG, technology and healthcare. In each case, these end markets are very large, growing and fragmented, and DCC has a clear ambition to take leadership positions. The group has a long track record of valuation discipline; group ROCE was 16.5% a decade ago. Following £2.1bn of acquisition spend, group ROCE was 17.5% in 2018. It has also integrated over 260 transactions since IPO. We have noted previously that this is a real competitive differentiator.

Flaneur sounds like a vehicle for chinese money....
11:44 am
BE11:44am

And RBC.

BE11:44am

We view today’s announcement as extremely positive and the placing as a statement of intent in terms of the scale of the consolidation opportunities in its core markets. DCC is currently trading on 21x 2019 PE (pre-today's announcement) which we don’t see as prohibitive for such a growth compounding story. We continue to believe DCC should be a key holding given the strength of its operating model, consistent cashflow and return characteristics and earnings upside potential from consolidation opportunities (as illustrated today) in its fragmented end markets. We reiterate our Outperform rating.

BE11:44am

You get the idea.

11:44 am
undefined
BE11:45am

Speaking of acquisitons, Clinigen requested.

BE11:46am

It's buying something called CSM Parent, which does specialist packaging and labeling and storage and stuff.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

Cost of $150m, with a further $90m kicker on earnings targets, funded by an £80m placing.

BE11:47am

Looks expensive.

BE11:47am

Here's Berenberg.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

While clearly in line with the company’s strategy, and with revenue synergies expected to be delivered in the near term, the 15x adjusted EBITDA multiple appears full.

Soundbuy Aren't UDG in the same area?
BE11:48am

So, costs need taken out to make things work.

BE11:49am

With revenue currently growing at 18%, and $1m of initial cost synergies, the adjusted run-rate multiple is c15x. Clinigen expects ROIC to reach 10% in year three before synergies, and net debt is expected to be 2.4x pro-forma EBITDA. It is expected to result in very small earnings accretion this year.
Management points to a complementary customer mix, and that some of its larger customers in CTS are very keen on added-value services in clinical trials. It also believes that there will be opportunities to leverage the new infrastructure in the Unlicensed and Commercial Medicines divisions.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

Oh, it's bought Qone as well. €7.5m

BE11:50am

Which " medical science liaison personnel to help Clinigen in its revitalisation efforts for recently acquired Commercial Medicines products Proleukin and Imukin," according to Peel Hunt.

BE11:51am

We will update our model to reflect these deals in due course, although we note that our forecast for FY2019 EBITDA of £104m is already substantially above consensus on £92m. Clinigen’s press release states pro-forma leverage post the £80m equity raise will be c2.4x net debt/EBITDA, falling “towards 2.0x” by June 2019.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

We view the newly announced acquisitions as both strategically and financially accretive. This, together with the robust underlying business and strong cash generation make Clinigen’s 15x 2019E P/E (on our current forecasts unadjusted for today’s news) highly attractive. Reiterate Buy.

undefined
BE11:52am

So ........... what else? It's mostly results, most of which aren't terribly exciting.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Saga was requested.

Saga PLC (SAGA:LSE): Last: 128.85, up 2.85 (+2.27%), High: 130.50, Low: 120.80, Volume: 2.43m
BE11:54am

Slightly better than expected numbers. Full-year guidance unchanged.

Fox Thanks.
11:54 am
BE11:55am

Outlook on the broking business relatively cautious tho.

Fox Interested to see what full year EPS forecast for Saga is given H1 was 7.7p
BE11:55am

The beat's on reserve releases -- a common theme across the whole insurance sector -- so should only really be worth one turn.

BE11:56am

And the divi's slowly eroding the capital ratios, though solvency's still at a pretty decent 156%.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Quick line from Bernstein.

BE11:56am

A key part of our thesis is that Saga would be able to resume customer growth in the broking business. Core policy numbers in motor and home were basically in line with our forecast and Saga also reported an improvement in retention (up 1ppt to 69.9%). We had been slightly worried going into results because of the tough conditions in motor insurance, with Hastings, Direct Line and Esure (prior to the Bain offer) all down 15-20% this year, but these numbers give us reassurance in our thesis. 'Other' core policies were down 6% due to travel. A short-term negative today was the cautious outlook for the second half in the broking business, with Saga reporting increasing margin pressure on net rates in home following the adverse weather in H1, which is "expected to impact broker revenue and profitability in the second half". In Motor, there is also headwind from lower average premium in H2.

BE11:57am

And in terms of forecasts, nothing much changes.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Since management is still on previous guidance for a 5% fall in full year profit. All we get is a small bit of balance sheet shift.

Fox Spire Healthcare Group dropped below 150p this morning. It was only last November that the board rejected a bid of 315p from Mediclinic. Penny for their thoughts?!
BE11:58am

Reflecting less broking and more underwriting profit

BE11:59am

UBS:

Alchemy30 Morning, apols Bryce but will ask why you mentioned GNC ? Thanks
11:59 am
BE12:00pm

We highlight: 1) Customer numbers recovering: Saga notes that customer
numbers are back to 1H17 levels despite a challenging environment for motor insurance, driven by a 19% increase in Motor and Home new business, helped by footprint expansion of the motor panel. 2) Continued momentum in bookings for the ships: Saga notes the first 19 cruises of the new ship (Spirit of Discovery) are now 64% booked (1Q18: 55%, UBSe: 58%). The first 5 cruises are now 90% sold, and construction of the ships is on track. 3) Reserve releases continue to run at elevated levels: The beat is mainly driven by reserve releases. Saga notes this is mostly driven by the current year (which is more sustainable than prior years), and strong performance of AICL should continue through 2H18E.

BE12:00pm

And Peel Hunt.

BE12:00pm

Overall, a refining of the broker operating model explains the muted 2018 H1 performance and earnings pressure. A string of new management appointments and improved governance should put Saga back on track to rebuild what we believe is an attractive and distinct affinity broker model. The shares are undervalued, trading at a 9x 2018/19E P/E, 7.5x EV/EBITDA, offering a 7% yield. We retain our Buy recommendation as we await a turnaround in the company’s fortunes.

12:01 pm

And if you want forecasts ..............

It's warned several times in the interim and investors now seem to have a better grasp of the NHS's strategy of using triage as a stealth method of privatising everything beyond first-line primary care, so the lost public business includes poor folk so doesn't have the counterweight of gained private business.)

And see you tomorrow, when the sun will be shining and grass will surely be greencore. Afternoon all.
